Award.AwardTitle: Support for Junior Investigators at the Orthopaedic Research Society Musculoskeletal Biology Workshop; Sun Valley, Idaho; August 6-9, 2017

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant will support young investigators at the 47th annual meeting of the Orthopaedic Research Society Musculoskeletal Biology Workshop being held in Sun Valley, Idaho, August 6-9, 2017. The workshop emphasizes active participation of junior faculty and students; promote interdisciplinary communication; and are unusual in that discussion time equals or exceeds time allotted for formal presentation. The goals of the workshop are to (1) Work toward a multidisciplinary basic and clinical synthesis of molecular, cellular, tissue and biomechanical processes that leads to understand the pathogenesis of musculoskeletal diseases, prevention and treatment; (2) Apply basic science concepts to clinical problems, developing a dialogue between basic and clinical investigators towards interdisciplinary collaboration; (3) Identify problems in musculoskeletal disease and experimental approaches that provide solutions to them; (4) Provide a forum for student training and the opportunity for junior scientists to talk with more senior scientists in a small group setting.

The workshop will continue the theme, "Solving Problems, Suggesting Solutions", targeting the basic science of the rare disease Fibrous Dysplasia and also of the chronic problem of Degenerative Disc Disease. Four sessions will address relevant and significant current problems, including progress in next-generation musculoskeletal therapies, imaging of musculoskeletal tissues, limitations and solutions for engineered animal models of disease, and finite element applications to clinical and basic science research. A notable feature of this Workshop is that it is becoming a truly musculoskeletal workshop, considering problems of musculoskeletal conditions beyond bone. Many opportunities are provided for junior investigators to interact with more senior investigators. A Career Development Workshop specifically geared toward young investigators will be held during one afternoon. This award will support travel awards for ten young investigators to attend this meeting. They will participate in the full meeting and in a special Sunday evening session devoted entirely to poster presentations, with some short poster presentations from the podium. All of their abstracts will be posted for public viewing on the ORS website prior to the Workshop.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of the Sun Valley Workshop is to improve understanding across the many disciplines that study musculoskeletal biology, to provide new perspectives that lead to prevention and/or treatment of musculoskeletal diseases, and to develop interdisciplinary collaborations, especially for younger scientists and scientists new to the field. The workshop receives support from the NIH, NSF, ASBMR, and AAA.

 

In 2017, it was the 47th Sun Valley Workshop and the 52nd year since the first Workshop was held in 1965. The theme for the 2017 Sun Valley Workshop was “Modern Methodologies and Novel Therapies.” Three sessions addressed novel and state of the art technical approaches: finite element analysis for basic and clinical studies, new techniques for imaging musculoskeletal tissues, and the use of genetically engineered animal models; and three sessions addressed mechanisms of disease and therapies of the musculoskeletal system: one problem in Endocrinology focusing on the rare bone disease Fibrous Dysplasia, one problem in Orthopaedics focusing on degenerative disk disease, and next generation therapies.

 

Thirty-three posters were presented at the Workshop, including posters from the 15 winners of the Young Investigator Awards, and the OA Award.  Three separate sessions were devoted to oral presentations from the 9 winners of the ASBMR/Harold M. Frost Award, and three other sessions to the 10 Blue Ribbon Sun Valley Poster presentations.

In 2017, 25 awards for junior investigators were given; all investigators presented their work from the podium or in a poster setting. Awards included 14 Alice L. Jee Memorial Travel Awards (including three to under-represented minority participants); 9 ASBMR/Harold M. Frost Awards; 1 award for osteoarthritis research; and 1 young investigator award in honor of Dr. Charles Turner.

 

The Career Development session geared toward junior investigators, chaired by Marjolein van der Meulen, focused on “Research Funding and Grant Writing.” It included an overview of Biomedical Research Funding by van der Meulen, NIH grants by Gayle Lester, NSF Grants by David Fyhrie, and panel discussion about grant writing advice for junior investigators, moderated by Teresita Bellido, with a panel composed of Alison Boyce, Chris Hernandez, Hollis Potter, James Iatridis, Susan Bloomfield, and John Fowlkes. There were more than 40 attendees at this session, with 9% of the attendees being graduate students, 50% postdoctoral fellows, and 16% Assistant Professors. 

 

Continuing a tradition of mentorship, lunches were arranged between young investigators award winners and more senior investigators selected from invited speakers and senior investigators who attended the meeting, who served as mentors. As an additional aspect of mentorship, we appointed a pre-workshop young investigator mentor, who worked prior to the Workshop with the young investigators on content and length of their presentations. An addition in 2017 in support of young investigators was the Blue Ribbon Poster and Presentation program in which selected posters were highlighted by 3 min-oral presentations.   

 

We are committed to the active participation of women in these Workshops. In 2017, 40% of the participants were women. Two of seven session chairs (28.6%) were women. Three of the eight members of the Advisory Board are women, and one of the Assistants to the Chair is a woman.

 

In 2017, 8% of the participants were under-represented minorities including 1 African-American and 3 Hispanic. We will continue to support URMs with young investigator and travel awards.  We will contact labs personally to make them aware that there will be at least five fellowships available only to underrepresented minorities (young investigator awards are open to any young investigator, and may include URM as well). 

 

These are some of the comments received for the 2017 meeting:

  1. Excellent networking and educational opportunities.
  2. Please keep the meeting at Sun Valley, this is a unique and wonderful venue
  3. The Blue Ribbon posters program was a successful addition, adding 2 min discussion to the 3 minute presentation could enhance interaction with the audience even more
  4. Excellent meeting, excellent organization.
  5. It's an excellent program!
  6. Really enjoyed this conference and the format very much, one of the best I have attended to date
  7. This is possibly the best conference I have been to.
  8. Please, continue to encourage the professors to approach and engage the younger students and researchers, as the mentoring aspect made this conference incredible
  9. Very well run meeting. Excellent venue and support system. Please keep doing it.

 

Respectfully submitted,

 

Teresita Bellido, PhD

Co-Chair, Sun Valley Workshop on Musculoskeletal Biology                       714 words, max 800 words
